item.title: Cards against malaria
item.description:
Genetic inheritance is often described as a game of cards. Which of the two alleles (versions) of a gene you get from each of your parents is random, so your genome is the result of being dealt a ‘genetic hand’ from each parent.

I explored this concept by developing a card game that aims to explain the role that your genes have in malaria susceptibility. Together with the amazing graphic designer Jakob Rossner from the Nuffield Department of Medicine in Oxford, we made Cards against malaria.

item.title: Our genomic future
item.description:
In September 2017 I won a small grant to produce a play about the challenges and opportunities of big data in medicine and healthcare. In early 2018 playwright Beth Flintoff came to work at the Big Data Institute in Oxford and has been busy writing a script. Local theatre company Reading Between the Lines.

We’re aiming to develop the play further over the course of 2018 so that we can take it to the Edinburgh Science Festival and Edinburgh International Festivals in 2019. For more info see the RBL page on project “Genomes”.
